review: Device obviates need for WIRED  connection from your laptop [or other internet connected device] so you can, in theory, stream wirelessly from your device to your TV.  Swell idea!Pros: Gorgeous packaging; easy wireless setup; background photos gorgeous; immediately able to cast youtube [so can now more easily watch watercolor demos on our tv].Cons:unable to cast AmazonPrime [not supported?]; initially, unable to cast from Netflix; above average tech savy; tried many work arounds, uninstalled/reinstalled Chrome, Starlight, restarts, reboots, blah blah; Google help uninformative and Apple no interest in getting this to work.unfortunately, cannot describe what DID work, but suddenly we are able to cast Netflix and it works fine.Still keeping old school wired Roku; less finicky.  Jus' sayin' dude....Chromecast device is still in Beta [or maybe junior high], but it may work fine for your needs. Troubleshooting lingo relies heavily on slang which is, at first blush, almost endearing; but gets old fast as frustrations mount and tends to exclude at least one third of USA population. Jus' sayin' dude ...ps this device [Chromecast] requires download and installation of Google's Chrome [Chromecast is not designed to work with Safari nor with Firefox].  A sudden shudder of massive-data-mining-paranoia caused us immediately to uninstall Chrome from our most-used computer and instead install the required Chrome on a less frequently used laptop which contains no 'data'.  During installation of Chrome, it was not crystal clear how reliable the privacy settings are/were/may be some day.  Naive, I know.  Jus' sayin' dude.....

review: Anyone who hasn't been living under a rock for the past few years probably owns a smartphone by now. And anyone who owns a home or rents, and owns a smartphone, probably has WIFI by now, too. The Chromecast plugs into an HDTV via HDMI and works in conjunction with your smartphone and a WIFI network.So, instead of spending hundreds of dollars more on an HDTV that has some built-in Smart TV capabilities like Netflix Streaming or DLNA support, just forego those and get yourself a cheaper DUMB TV and a Google CHROMECAST instead. And if you already have a dumb TV with an HDMI input, a smartphone and WIFI, then the Chromecast is the cheapest streaming device out there. Heck, you could turn a large PC monitor that has HDMI into a smart TV, if you were so inclined.It was a bit of a pain to setup, but after an hour and a few  router reconfigurations later, I had everything running smoothly.It works beautifully. No interface lag whatsoever. HBO GO and Netflix look outstanding. Highly Recommended!------If there is only one complaint that I have, it's this:GOOGLE, PLEASE ALLOW PEOPLE TO CONFIGURE THE NETWORK SETTINGS. I WOULD LIKE TO BE ABLE TO SET A STATIC IP ADDRESS FOR MY CHROMECAST.
